Posts.Title: Update on Secondary Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maximus Well I guess the title sort of says it all. In a couple of weeks I am scheduled to have a cystoscopy (for blood in the urine) and a prostate biopsy (family history of PCa, PSA of 11, African-American) on the same day - back to back. I will be sedated with a benzodiazepine and will receive local anesthesia. I'm wondering if this seems like a lot to you to have both of these procedures together), or if anyone has gone through having these back to back like that. I'm not looking forward to it to say the least. Technically, this seems to be more "front to back"....? Sorry, couldn't resist. I'm with everyone else, think getting both done on the same day makes sense, especially with the sedation. I also went through both (blood in urine too) without sedation; while both are not pleasant experiences, they're not that bad. Best of luck to you, please keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy AND Cystoscopy

Posts.Content: Hi Vince, Sorry to welcome you to the forum, I hope having your RALP behind you is giving you some well earned peace of mind. My experience was similar to yours (please see my signature below), and have shared in a previous post: I opted for surgery given my age, overall health (good), and like many others hoped to hold the radiation card for the future. After surgery with final not-so-good pathology in hand, my surgeon advised we would be discussing adjuvant radiation at my first post-op PSA appointment. Three months later the wife and I were thrilled to see PSA results were <0.01, and surprised when surgeon suggested holding off on radiation plans until next visit. His rational was there is much healing taking place at this time after surgery, and given the "0" PSA level his reco was to hold off radiation plans until next PSA reading. If the needle moved, we'd proceed with what would still be considered adjuvant therapy (vs salvage). Since then, we've been blessed with three PSA readings of <0.01 and have since moved the "R" card to my back pocket. I can appreciate your disappointment at the margins, been there. You've been treated at a leading PC facility, and it sounds like they're making an informed call that your positive margin is not a concern. As others may comment, this happens more often than you might expect. I'm assuming you've been told your PC was organ confined (might want to add this to your signature)? My reco would be to follow the experts advice; worst case if your PSA numbers indicate activity you will still have the option of adjuvant radiation. I was very lucky with continence, never had an issue (ok, exception for too much beer + good belly laughs). They did have to scoop wide around one nerve, so ED definitely present but every month still seems to be getting better. Best of luck with that August appointment, Groot
Posts.Signature: Age at DX: 58 PSA: 4.9 Positive DRE Biopsy: 12/7/15 Left Mid Adenocarcinoma 1/12 cores (45%) Gleason 4+3=7, CT abdomen, bone scan negative RALP 1/27/16 at CINJ/RWJ (New Brunswick, NJ) Surgeon: Dr Isaac Kim (1400+ procedures, highly recommend) Final Pathology: 2/1/16 7 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles negative Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin involved by invasive carcinoma Gleason score 5+4=9 with intraductal component Primary tumor pT2: organ confined, high grade PIN Four post-op exams: PSA <0.01
Posts.Title: Post-Op biopsy shows cancer at margins, no therapy recommended - your opinion?

Posts.Content: Dear FB's & FS's, Hoping you won't mind if I vent a bit, life's been a roller coaster lately, assume many of you can relate. The first arc of that "circle of life" is a bitter one. I lost my 73 year old sister last week after a nine year courageous fight against endometrial cancer. I'm preparing for her life ceremony today, truly one of the nicest people New Jersey had. News flash for anyone on this site: cancer, of any kind, sucks. Alas, the circle also has a shiny side. My wife and I just became first time grandparents, a beautiful, healthy baby girl. She brought us all, sister included, much happiness during a difficult time. Between all of the above, I get a call from my older brother who's been battling mental illness most of his adult life. His PSA results came back over 5, and needs to make an appointment with a urologist. Oh boy, here we go.... Aside from being a bit dizzy from all the above, think I'm doing ok with my PC battle. I go for my 3+ year PSA test next month. This is my first one year stretch between tests, but with everything going on have not had much time to think about that G9.... Forum bothers and sisters, stay strong and keep up the good fight! And thanks for letting me blow off some steam!!!
Posts.Signature: Age at DX: 58 PSA: 4.9 Positive DRE Biopsy: 12/7/15 Left Mid Adenocarcinoma 1/12 cores (45%) Gleason 4+3=7, CT abdomen, bone scan negative RALP 1/27/16 at CINJ/RWJ (New Brunswick, NJ) Surgeon: Dr Isaac Kim (1400+ procedures, highly recommend) Final Pathology: 2/1/16 7 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles negative Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin involved by invasive carcinoma Gleason score 5+4=9 with intraductal component Primary tumor pT2: organ confined, high grade PIN Four post-op exams: PSA <0.01
Posts.Title: Circle of life

Posts.Content: Congratulations Cubsfan on putting your primary treatment behind you! My experience was very similar to yours, very smooth surgical procedure followed with a disappointing path report (Gleason upgrade, IDC, pos margin...see my sig below) not what you want to hear. But hang in there, as MF suggested there is a good chance your surgery was a success. My surgeon said we'd be planning AR when I came back for first post-op PSA checkup, but when level came back <0.01 he suggested to wait another 3 months to allow the healing to continue. I'm now out 18 months and hopefully still in the "zero" club (getting tested next week). I can't say how your treatment plans might be affected by your IDC, but given this showed up on my path report too, will see if I can get my docs perspective. Happy to share if I learn anything useful. Best of luck to you, and Keegle On!

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your kind replies, it's much appreciated especially after such a sad day. I've been a steady visitor to this forum for the past 3 years, and try to contribute a few occasional words of hope when I see a similar diagnosis to mine. But you guys go above and beyond, words of encouragement and knowledge for all. If there was such a thing as "buying a digital round", I'd be doing so right now

Posts.Title: Fingers Crossed

Posts.Content: Hi Mark, Given my situation was similar to yours, thought I would share my experience. My biopsy came in as a 4+3=7 and had a positive DRE, so urologist was clear action was required. I was 58 at the time, and was advised I could go either way (surgery vs. RT). If I was older, he would have advised RT, younger would have been surgery. After doing much homework (as you're doing now), I opted for surgery. One of the reasons I went this way was to hold onto the option of future RT to the pelvic area, if needed (i.e. for PC BCR or other pelvic issues like colon, etc). RT technology is constantly improving, so this may not be a factor for you, easy enough for you to discuss with the experts. As other FB's have shared with you, it looks like you've caught this aggressive issue early and you have an excellent chance to be cured. Following surgery, my pathology report bumped me up to a 5+4=9 which was a big surprise. The plan was then to follow up with ART, pending my 3 month PSA results. Fortunately, with PSA <0.01 the ART plans were put on hold, and now at 2 years+ still holding at <0.01 (yay!). I've been remarkably lucky with continence, no issues other than occasional dribble (good beer+good laughs). ED not bad, sildenafil keeps the equipment working just fine (did have to give up partial nerve). One regret I have is I did not have genomic testing done. If you follow DJ's sticky you can get a good idea of the information you can gain, another topic worth discussing with the experts. Hang in there, keep doing your homework, and best of luck to you with whatever course of action you choose! Please keep us posted.
Posts.Signature: Age at DX: 58 PSA: 4.9 Positive DRE Biopsy: 12/7/15 Left Mid Adenocarcinoma 1/12 cores (45%) Gleason 4+3=7, CT abdomen, bone scan negative RALP 1/27/16 at CINJ/RWJ (New Brunswick, NJ) Surgeon: Dr Isaac Kim (1400+ procedures, highly recommend) Final Pathology: 2/1/16 7 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles negative Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin involved by invasive carcinoma Gleason score 5+4=9 with intraductal component Primary tumor pT2: organ confined, high grade PIN Four post-op exams: PSA <0.01
Posts.Title: PSA 9-10, Gleason 8, Good News

Posts.Content: I call BS on doc #1. OK, maybe that's a bit harsh. IMHO, continence does seem to be related to surgical technique, perhaps our senior members can weigh in here. With the volume of procedures you've mentioned, they certainly have experience. I was lucky in this department, very good control at 4 months so it is possible. Was surgeon #1 able to give you confidence based on YOUR situation which stat would be yours (97% vs the other 3%)? I.e. is he confirming your tumor location will allow both nerves to be spared? I thought you had concerns about this in a previous post, would be good news if this is no longer a concern. In my case, one of my nerves was involved so I'm still dealing with ED. Fully functional with Sildenafil, sometimes without but that took more than a year of healing. For what it's worth, my surgeon told me to expect this up front (due to nodule location during DRE). I appreciated he was talking about my situation, not "general stats" and one of the reasons I went with him. And just curious, do both surgeons plan up front on taking any lymph nodes? Bottom line, I'm aligned with previous member responses, doc#2 sounds more realistic.
Posts.Signature: Age at DX: 58 PSA: 4.9 Positive DRE Biopsy: 12/7/15 Left Mid Adenocarcinoma 1/12 cores (45%) Gleason 4+3=7, CT abdomen, bone scan negative RALP 1/27/16 at CINJ/RWJ (New Brunswick, NJ) Surgeon: Dr Isaac Kim (1400+ procedures, highly recommend) Final Pathology: 2/1/16 7 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles negative Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin involved by invasive carcinoma Gleason score 5+4=9 with intraductal component Primary tumor pT2: organ confined, high grade PIN Four post-op exams: PSA <0.01

Posts.Content: Pratoman, No pictures? COULD have been my favorite post EVER! Whatever, thanks for sharing the info. While I'm currently enjoying my zero club status, I know I'm sitting in the high risk section, so slowly trying to get a feel for latest thoughts on trigger points for salvage treatments. My surgeon has moved me to the 6 mo test cycle, not sure how comfortable I am with this given not so good path report. Best of luck to you and your family, and enjoy your break. Sounds like you're getting top shelf care, so be convinced you're earned a break. But next time you see your PA, pls remember to bring your cell and "take one for the team"...

Posts.Title: My Follow Up with surgeon 20 months post op

Posts.Content: Hi 46, Hopefully your panic has turned down a notch after reading the solid feedback and support from our FB's. I don't have any advice beyond what's already been shared, but did want to respond given my situation was not too different from yours. If you look at my signature, you can see I also had relatively low PSA, positive DRE, and a Gleason 9. You have more PC volume than I did, but my G9 was the less "desirable" 5+4 (with an intraductal cherry on top??). I'm now about 2 1/2 years post op, and PSA continues to be <0.01 thanks to a skillful surgeon and early detection. As you've already been advised, focus that nervous energy on learning your treatment options. Best of luck to you with your scans, and please keep us posted. If you have any other questions, you know where to find us!

Posts.Content: Hi 46, Hopefully your panic has turned down a notch after reading the solid feedback and support from our FB's. I don't have any advice beyond what's already been shared, but did want to respond given my situation was not too different from yours. If you look at my signature, you can see I also had relatively low PSA, positive DRE, and a Gleason 9. You have more PC volume than I did, but my G9 was the less "desirable" 5+4 (with an intraductal cherry on top??). I'm now about 2 1/2 years post op, and PSA continues to be <0.01 thanks to a skillful surgeon and early detection. As you've already been advised, focus that nervous energy on learning your treatment options. Best of luck to you with your scans, and please keep us posted. If you have any other questions, you know where to find us!

Posts.Title: How I dealt with my Geason 10 diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Keith, Congratulations on putting the worst part of your journey behind you, and glad to hear the healing process is going well. You've already gotten what I consider good advice from our FB&S's, all eyes on that next PSA. My path report had a few similarities to yours, and I was on a similar course to yours for follow up treatment. In my case, my 3mo PSA came in at <0.01 which was a pleasant surprise. The bigger surprise was my uro suggested holding off the ART initiation until next PSA, saying this would still be considered adjuvant. My wife and I did struggle with this, as we were very prepared to "hit this hard and early with all we've got". We did decide to follow his advice, and so far we've kept additional treatments on the shelf. Please keep us posted as you learn more, and if you have any more questions we're here to help. Best of luck to you!

Posts.Title: Adjuvent or Salvage Radiation?

Posts.Content: Sudds, Sorry to hear about that bad luck streak, hang in there, better times will come. For what it's worth, my pathology report took a similar "dive" to yours, not the news you want to hear. While I'm not an MD, your report looks like there's a good chance your cancer was organ confined, so you may be further along the road to cure than you think. Just curious, did you have any scans as part of your work up? I my case, we were planning on ART, but first PSA came in <0.01 so decided (surgeons reco) to wait for second PSA. I'm now out about 18 months, still in the "zero" club. For now, try to stay focused on healing as you make your plans for your next steps. As you probably already know, the FB's here are ready and willing to help with support and information. Please keep us posted, time for some GOOD luck!

Posts.Title: Brother diagnosed today

Posts.Content: Can't help you with your specific question; in my case, got my diagnosis during open enrollment and was able to change my plan to cover out of network. As it ended up, I wound up choosing a surgeon that was in network. Have to say I'm with Ron and Chuck, if there's any way to swing the 1500+ option I don't think you'll regret it. At the very least, I'm hoping you've had a detailed discussion about your specific situation with each surgeon; do they feel both nerves can be spared? What is their track record for patients maintaining continence? Surgical technique is critical in these two areas, not to mention the most critical complete removal of any suspect tissue. There are many successful procedures being performed by lower volume surgeons, but if you have the opportunity to improve your odds even a little, it's worth considering. Best of luck to you whichever way you go.

My surgeon has not gone there, and I'm VERY ok with that FYI, I still see surgeon for post RALP PSA testing vs urologist since his practice is around the corner from my office. Keep up the good work Arthur!

Posts.Title: For years out and still in the "zero club"

Posts.Content: Congratulations Dave on the great results, and thanks for posting those studies. I had to pull out my path report and check, must have read that thing 100 times but couldn't recall the size of my margin...2mm, so you made my day, thanks!! 35coupe, I think all of us that consider ourselves at risk or high risk have to learn to cope with the potential for "bad" news. Dave's got a great attitude; for many of us there are well defined next steps to fight this beast. Personally, I don't go "crazy" waiting for my results...though I might look like I am. I try to do something positive with that nervous energy about a week before testing, like knock out the wife's "honey-do" list

Posts.Title: 3 Month Post Op and Encouragement for Those with + Margins

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about your cardiac surprise, I can appreciate what you're going through as you try to put your PC issues behind, especially at 48 and being a gym rat. If misery likes company, 2016 was my year to forget. My signature gives you the PC story; I too had heart issues (right branch bundle block) that manifested into worsening Afib. Cardiologist had been urging cardiac laser ablation surgery for a few years, given otherwise very healthy, jogger (NOT runner), basketball, etc. After PC treatment, decided best to get the heart straightened out in case the PC takes a turn for the worse. The cherry on top was I had a mild hernia going into the PC surgery. Surgeon agreed to patch this while in there removing the prostate, but got timed out due to complications and having another procedure lined up behind me. So had to book a follow up open hernia op, since laparoscopic was off the table given scaring from RALP. Have to admit, was kind of a yawn after the other two procedures. So three surgeries in one year, formally making 16 my unlucky number. But all has turned out for the best; Afib has been cured, back to running and Bball, no more Afib. Chopping wood, because I can. And hoping for another <0.01 PSA reading come September. Hang in there, you had the strength to beat the alcohol. Sounds like the worst of your PC is behind you (might want to update your signature?). Take one day at a time, do your homework and make good decisions. Such as lending me the keys to that 68RS.... Please keep us posted.
